descriptionProfile: Explorer, photojournalist, veteran contributor to Nat Geo & many others. Sharing reflections from a long career celebrating earth’s wildest places.
Explorer, photojournalist, veteran contributor to Nat Geo & many others. Sharing reflections from a long career celebrating earth’s wildest places.

posts.description: Happy Earth Day!  We all live in a delicate balance between the powerful forces of the natural world and our human ambitions to tame them in search of growth and material weatlh. When I was still in high school, first learning about pollution and "the environment," the first Earth Day in 1970 inspired me to walk several miles to to school, rather than drive and the event helped me to appreciate the actual fragility of the spectacular Owens Valley where I lived, shown here sandwiched between the towering Sierra Nevada in the foreground and White Mountains in the background. The spirit of preservation celebrated on this day is even more important now than ever before. We are all in this together and it's up to us to preserve and protect the Earth, it's natural beauty, ecosystems and all it's creatures. #earthday #conservation

A soldier guards the #parliament building in #Ulaanbaatar, #Mongolia. As I think about conflict in the world today, it is good helpful to remember that humans have been conquering each other as long as the dawn of civilization. But I shudder to think of what a man like #GenghisKhan might have accomplished with tools of war that we have today! #architecture

Towering #lenticular #clouds glow in a #sunset over the Lamar Valley in #Yellowstone National Park, #Wyoming. These magnificent formations are a common sight in rugged mountains, where moist air is forced high into the Troposphere where water vapor hovers in long, multiple layers of lens-shaped clouds that can hover in place for hours. Some scientists suggest that these may be the source for many reports of UFOs. #nationalpark #landscape

#Pacific #Ocean waves roll ashore on the #California coast near Black Point in #Sonoma County. Thanks to the record-breaking rainfall this year, the whole state is beginning to glow green again after long years of drought.

Two striated caracaras, aka "Johnny Rooks," squabble over a fence post on New Island, an outpost in the #Falkland / #Malvinas Islands in the South Atlantic. These #birds are mainly scavengers, but they will also prey on weak or injured creatures. Their taste for newborn lambs and weakened sheep has led them to be reviled by local sheep farmers. #birds #fight

During an assignment to photograph the Wadi Rum in #Jordan, my climbing companion Lisa Gnade #runs in the shadow of a towering Jebel (mountain outcrop). This spectacular landscape at the edge of the Arabian #Desert was the setting for David Lean's epic movie Lawrence of Arabia. #running #explore #WadiRum #Jordan

When I stopped my horse at a ger (yurt) in the remote #DarhadValley of northern #Mongolia, these venerable #sisters, Ayush and Bayar, learned that I was taking pictures for National Geographic and scrambled to find nicer clothes. They didn't even think about the magazine, which they had never seen, but they wanted to look their best in a polaroid portrait that I had offered in exchange for my pictures. What their silk robes belie is their lifelong bond to the landscapes around them. Both had started riding horses practically from the times they could walk and have been nomads for all of their years, herding camels, goats, sheep and cattle across central Asian steppes while still managing ever-moving hearths for their families. I see deep pride in their faces and wonder if many of us more "civilized" people can share as much at similar ages. #portraits

Let's go camping he said, it'll be fun!" Tip: When venturing into the outdoors, tell your friends it will be an "adventure," never promise "a good time." Here @conrad_anker struggles to set up his tent in a raging #blizzard near Mount Vinson, the highest mountain in #Antarctica. Not only might his tent get airborne, he might blow away, too. #camping #fun

Night after night, through moonlight, fog, or rain, the Point #Montara #Lighthouse warns ships off of treacherous reefs just south of #SanFrancisco, #California. It was first constructed with just a simple kerosene lantern in 1875, upgraded with a more powerful Fresnel lens in 1912, and finally rehoused in 1928 with a tower imported around Cape Horn from the Mayo Beach Lighthouse on Cape Cod, Massachusetts. The light still blinks today and the surrounding buildings now serve as a youth hostel. #pacific

Happy Losar, the first day of the Tibetan New Year of the Fire Rooster! It is debatable, however, whether more people in #Lhasa (the capital city of the former independent nation of #Tibet) will be celebrating the annual festival as "Chinese" New Year instead. Back in 1986 when I shot this picture of the Potala (the historic home of the now exiled Dalai Lama), Chinese people were a distinct minority in the city. Now, however, after three decades of massive inflow from more populated parts of China, Tibetans, themselves, may be the minority and this sacred city and this panorama has been almost completely transformed. Although the Potala still stands as a tourist attraction, the prayer flags are gone, the scene is cluttered with new concrete buildings and Buddhism is actively repressed. Some of the happier celebrants of Losar today may be the Tibetans now living in exile, still led by the Dalai Lama who has, as spiritual leader of Tibetan Buddhists, introduced this ancient religion to new adherents around the world. #Losar #yearoftherooster #prayerflags #potala #dalailama
